standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Relate fraction division to fraction multiplication

question.content: Sandra wants to use multiplication to solve $\dfrac14 \div 6 = {t}$.  **Which multiplication equation can Sandra use?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenE{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenE{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.  The $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenE{6}$.    The $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$ is ${\maroonD{t}}$.

images.alt: Tape diagram showing 1 fourth is equal to 6 equal groups of t

hints.content: So, we can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{t}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD6$,  to get the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$, $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.
Sandra can use this multiplication equation:   - ${t} \times 6 = \dfrac14$

question.content: Nell wants to use multiplication to solve ${m} = \dfrac12 \div 8$.  **Which multiplication equation can Nell use?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenE{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenE{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$.  The $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenE{8}$.    The $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$ is ${\maroonD{m}}$.

images.alt: Tape diagram showing 1 half is equal to 8 equal groups of m

hints.content: So, we can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{m}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD8$,  to get the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$, $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$.
Nell  can use this multiplication equation:   - $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}} = \greenE{8} \times \maroonD{m}$

question.content: Emily wants to use multiplication to solve $\dfrac15 \div 3 = {a}$.  **Which multiplication equation can Emily use?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenE{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenE{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$.  The $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenE{3}$.    The $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$ is ${\maroonD{a}}$.

images.alt: Tape diagram showing 1 fifth is equal to 3 equal groups of a

hints.content: So, we can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{a}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD3$,  to get the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$, $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$.
Emily can use this multiplication equation:  - $\dfrac15=3\times{a}$

question.content: Hanna wants to use multiplication to solve  $2 \div \dfrac14 = {c}$.  **Which multiplication equation can Hanna use?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenE{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenE{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleD{2}$.   The $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$ is ${\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  The $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenE{c}$.

images.alt: Two bars of unequal length. The bars are left aligned. The top bar is longer. It is labeled 2. The bottom bar is much shorter. It is labeled one-fourth. Below both bars is a curved bracket labeled c equal groups.

hints.content: So, we can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{c}$,  to get the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$, $\purpleD{2}$.
Hanna can use this multiplication equation:  - ${c} \times\dfrac14 = 2$

question.content: Howard wants to use multiplication to solve  ${w} = 5 \div \dfrac15$.  **Which multiplication equation can Howard use?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenE{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenE{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleD{5}$.   The $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$ is ${\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  The $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenE{w}$.

images.alt: Two bars of unequal length. The bars are left aligned. The top bar is longer. It is labeled 5. The bottom bar is much shorter. It is labeled one-fifth. Below both bars is a curved bracket labeled w equal groups.

hints.content: So, we can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{w}$,  to get the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$, $\purpleD{5}$.
Howard can use this multiplication equation:  - $5=\dfrac15\times{w}$

question.content: Rick wants to use multiplication to solve  ${k} = 7 \div \dfrac13$.  **Which multiplication equation can Rick use?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenE{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenE{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleD{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \greenE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleD{7}$.   The $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$ is ${\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}}$.   [[☃ image 1]]    The $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenE{k}$.

images.alt: Two bars of unequal length. The bars are left aligned. The top bar is longer. It is labeled 7. The bottom bar is much shorter. It is labeled one-third. Below both bars is a curved bracket labeled k equal groups.

hints.content: So, we can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac13}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{k}$,  to get the $\purpleD{\text{total}}$, $\purpleD{7}$.
Rick can use this multiplication equation:   - $\dfrac13\times{k} =7$

question.content: **Which equation shows the same relationship as $42=7\div\dfrac{1}{6}$?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenD{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \greenD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
In this fact family, the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleC{7}$.  The $\maroonD{\text{size of each group}}$ is $\maroonD{42}$.  The $\greenD{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenD{\dfrac16}$.
So, we can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{42}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$,  to get the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC7$.
This number sentence show the same relationship:  - $7=\dfrac16\times42$

question.content: **Which equation shows the same relationship as $72 \times \dfrac18 = 9$?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenD{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \greenD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
In this fact family, the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleC{9}$.  The $\maroonD{\text{size of each group}}$ is $\maroonD{72}$.  The $\greenD{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenD{\dfrac18}$.

We can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{72}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$,  to get the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC9$.  We can also divide the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC9$, by $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{72}$, or the $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$.
This number sentence show the same relationship:  - $72=9\div\dfrac{1}{8}$

question.content: **Which equation shows the same relationship as $4=\dfrac15\times20$?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenD{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \greenD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleC{4}$.  The $\maroonD{\text{size of each group}}$ is $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$.  The $\greenD{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenD{20}$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars of equal lengths. The top bar is labeled 4. The bottom bar is divided into 20 equal parts. Each part is labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket below both bars is labeled 20 equal groups.

hints.content: We can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{20}$,  to get the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC4$.  We can also divide the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC4$, by $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$, or the $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{20}$.
This number sentence show the same relationship:  - $4\div20=\dfrac15$

question.content: **Which equation shows the same relationship as $\dfrac14 \div 2 = \dfrac{1}{8}$?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenD{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \greenD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleC{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.  The $\maroonD{\text{size of each group}}$ is $\maroonD{\dfrac18}$.  The $\greenD{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenD{2}$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars of equal length. The top bar is labeled one-fourth. The bottom bar is divided into two equal parts. Each part is labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket below both bars is labeled 2 equal groups.

hints.content: We can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac18}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{2}$,  to get the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC{\dfrac14}$.  We can also divide the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC{\dfrac14}$, by $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac18}$, or the $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{2}$.
This number sentence show the same relationship:  - $\dfrac1{4}=2\times\dfrac1{8}$

question.content: **Which equation shows the same relationship as $\dfrac12 = 3\times\dfrac{1}{6}$?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenD{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \greenD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleC{\dfrac{1}{2}}$.  The $\maroonD{\text{size of each group}}$ is $\maroonD{\dfrac16}$.  The $\greenD{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenD{3}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars of equal length. The top bar is labeled one-half. The bottom bar is divided into three equal parts. Each part is labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket below both bars is labeled 3 equal groups.

hints.content: We can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac16}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{3}$,  to get the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC{\dfrac12}$.  We can also divide the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC{\dfrac12}$, by $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac16}$, or the $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{3}$.
This number sentence show the same relationship:  - $\dfrac1{2}\div3=\dfrac1{6}$

question.content: **Which equation shows the same relationship as $2= 4\times\dfrac{1}{2}$?**

hints.content: Multiplication and division are related:  $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{number of groups}} \times \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \times \greenD{\text{number of groups}} = \purpleC{\text{total}} \\\\ \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \greenD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleC{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\greenD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$

In this fact family, the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$ is $\purpleC{2}$.  The $\maroonD{\text{size of each group}}$ is $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$.  The $\greenD{\text{number of the groups}}$ is $\greenD{4}$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars of equal length. The top bar is labeled 2. The bottom bar is divided into four equal parts. Each part is labeled one-half. A curved bracket below both bars is labeled 4 equal groups.

hints.content: We can multiply the $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$, and $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{4}$,  to get the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC{2}$.  We can also divide the $\purpleC{\text{total}}$, $\purpleC{2}$, by $\maroonD{\text{size of the groups}}$, $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$, or the $\greenE{\text{number of the groups}}$, $\greenD{4}$.
This number sentence show the same relationship:  - $2\div4=\dfrac1{2}$
